mirai 0.7.2.9005

mirai Server (Async Executor Daemon)

Source: R/mirai.R
server.Rd

Implements a persistent executor/server for the remote process. Awaits data, evaluates an expression in an environment containing the supplied data, and returns the result to the caller/client.

server(
  url,
  nodes = NULL,
  baseurl = NULL,
  idletime = Inf,
  runtime = Inf,
  tasks = Inf
)

Arguments

url

the client URL and port to connect to as a character string e.g. 'tcp://192.168.0.2:5555'.

nodes

[default NULL] if supplied, this server instance will run as an active queue (task scheduler) with the specified number of nodes.

baseurl

[default NULL] if supplied (together with 'nodes'), the client URL for nodes to connect to with a starting port number e.g. 'tcp://192.168.0.2:5555' with 6 nodes uses the contiguous block of ports 5555 through 5560. Otherwise, nodes are automatically launched on the same machine.

idletime

[default Inf] maximum idle time, since completion of the last task (in milliseconds) before exiting.

runtime

[default Inf] soft walltime, or the minimum amount of real time taken (in milliseconds) before exiting.

tasks

[default Inf] the maximum number of tasks to execute (task limit) before exiting.

Value

Invisible NULL.

Details

The network topology is such that server daemons dial into the client, which listens at the '.url' address. In this way, network resources may be easily added or removed at any time and the client automatically distributes tasks to all available servers.

If 'nodes' is supplied, this daemon is launched as an active server queue, directing a cluster with the specified number of nodes. A server queue may be used in combination with other servers or server queues.

If 'baseurl' is also supplied, this active server queue allocates and listens to a block of URLs with ports starting from the supplied port number and incrementing by one. Individual server instances should then be started on the remote resource, with these as the client 'url'.

If 'nodes' is supplied without 'baseurl' then the 'nodes' are launched automatically by the active server queue on the same machine.
